title: us democratic
story: The process to choose the Democratic nominee to take on Donald Trump in November’s US presidential election is well under way.States across the country are in the process of choosing&nbsptheir preferred candidate, either through a primary contest or a caucus. A primary is a traditional election where eligible voters select their candidate privately through a ballot system. A caucus is a public process which sees voters align publicly with their chosen candidate at caucus sites.Based roughly on their share of the vote in each state - states have different rules -&nbspcandidates are assigned a number of “delegates”, which will be sent to represent each state at the Democratic National Convention in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, in July.On March 3rd – Super Tuesday – 14 states and one overseas territory voted. After a faltering start to the primaries that almost saw him written off, former vice-president Joe Biden got his campaign firmly on track with victory in nine states. Though Vermont senator Bernie Sanders finished first in four states, including delegate-rich California, Super Tuesday checked the Sanders momentum after a strong opening to the primaries in Iowa, New Hampshire and&nbspNevada.On March 10th&nbspsix more states vote, with most of the remaining primaries taking place throughout March and April. The final primary contest takes place on June 7th. However, by the end of March, well over 50 per cent of the delegates will have been allocated.In order to be selected as the party’s nominee at the convention in July, a candidate needs a majority of 50 per cent of delegates plus one, so the magic number is 1,991 pledged delegates out of the total of 3,979.However, with four candidates remaining in the race - Elizabeth Warren and Tulsi Gabbard complete the field, after Michael&nbspBloomberg’s&nbspwithdrawal -&nbspit is possible that no one candidate will have a majority of delegates when Democrats convene in July.Though the rules were changed after the 2016 convention following tensions between the Sanders and Hillary Clinton campaigns, so-called superdelegates - unpledged delegates - still play a role. These are senior members of the party – governors, former members of Congress, etc. Their 771 votes come into play if the convention is contested, which is&nbspa possibility.Notably, six of the candidates were asked during a debate in Las Vegas on February 19th if they would support the idea of a candidate winning the nomination if they secured a plurality but not a majority of the delegates. All but one – Sanders – said they were opposed to this. The issue may become a headache for the Democratic Party as the primary process progresses.

title: introducing planet normal new telegraph podcast talks normal
story: Sick of gotcha political coverage? Tired of the relentless negativity of the news cycle? Bored of endlessly cynical mainstream broadcasters?Then this is the podcast you’ve been looking for: Planet Normal - because some journalists are normal people too.Yet Pearson and Halligan have much in common. They both boast high-level political access – and lace politics into their writing, although rarely from a “Westminster village” perspective. They both have older children and, unlike so many London-centric journalists, live outside the M25.What unites them, above all, is that Pearson and Halligan are staunchly and proudly “normal” – both hailing from unflashy, proletarian, non-professional backgrounds, the first in their respective families to go to university. That’s one reason they share a reputation for shrewd political analysis and trend-spotting - knowing in their bones, often before the Westminster crowd, how “ordinary people” think.“You know that moment when you’re watching a TV panel discussion and finally – finally! – someone says something you agree with,” says Pearson. “That’s what Planet Normal is all about!”Pearson and Halligan have between them spent almost forty years penning national newspaper columns, winning countless awards for their writing and broadcasting. They both feel strongly that the media is now far less representative of the broader UK population than when they started out.“It’s become much harder in recent years for people from ordinary backgrounds to break into high-end journalism,” says Halligan. “We've made progress in terms of gender and ethnic ersity, but there’s now far less ersity in terms of opinion – with much of the broadcast media, in particular, dominated by privileged insiders holding the same approved views”.Planet Normal is a small but spirited attempt to counter that. In their 30-minute weekly podcast, Pearson and Halligan will review the news in the same sharp, irreverent, down-to-earth style they bring to their writing. The emphasis will be on calling out pomposity, lifting the lid on reality and countering political spin.And, on their trips to Planet Normal, Pearson and Halligan will be bringing along fabulous guests for the ride, representing all parts of the news cosmos – from politics to showbiz, from finance to culture – while responding to questions from Planet Normal listeners.Planet Normal - because some journalists are normal people too.To make sure you never miss an episode, subscribe on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, Pocket Casts, or search 'Planet Normal' on your podcast app.Join Liam Halligan and Allison Pearson in the comments section of this article at 1pm (BST) today to discuss their new podcast and more.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: emily maitlis overstepped mark says bbc new statement cummings
story: The BBC has doubled down on its censure of Emily Maitlis by saying she had “overstepped the mark” in her Newsnight monologue, after the corporation was flooded with complaints about her treatment.Initially, the BBC released a short statement saying the presenter had breached impartiality rules. The public reprimand left Ms Maitis so upset that she asked to be dropped from Wednesday night’s programme.By Thursday afternoon, at least 20,000 people had contacted the BBC to complain. Some were objecting to Ms Maitlis’s speech, but the majority are thought to have been criticising the BBC’s handling of the affair. Supporters had circulated a link on social media to the BBC complaints website.Colleague of Ms Maitlis were also in “uproar” over the reprimand.In a response that threatens to inflame the situation further, the BBC released a lengthy explanation for its actions. The broadcaster said: “Our editorial guidelines allow us to make professional judgments but not to express opinion.“The iding line can be fine, but we aim to say so if we think we have overstepped the mark.It said Ms Maitlis’s introduction “risked giving the perception that the BBC was taking sides and expressing an opinion, rather than being impartial.”Ms Maitlis had asserted that: “Dominic Cummings broke the rules. The country can see that and it’s shocked the Government cannot.” She added that people who had stuck to the rules now felt like “fools”.The BBC said: “But there are some who do not share this opinion, nor think that the issue is a ‘scandal’ or the Prime Minister has displayed ‘blind loyalty’.“By presenting a matter of public and political debate as if the country was unanimous in its view, we consider Newsnight risked giving the perception that the BBC was taking sides. It added: “Our audiences hold the BBC in high trust, not least because we hold ourselves to exacting standards, and we do not want to forfeit this by ignoring our own rules.”The statement insisted that “this is not a question of apportioning blame to anyone”. But it is likely to infuriate Newsnight colleagues who believe Ms Maitlis was vindicated by the police statement on Mr Cummings’ trip to Barnard Castle.The matter will now be investigated formally by the BBC’s executive complaints unit if any of the complainants choose to pursue it - raising the possibility that Ms Maitlis may end up being cleared of a rule breach.Maitlis confirmed that she had “asked for the night off” from Wednesday’s programme, dismissing reports that the BBC had replaced her with another presenter.Sources within the BBC said there is a great deal of anger over the decision by the BBC News department, led by Fran Unsworth, to issue the statement.They argued that Newsnight is not a straight news programme in the mould of the Six O’Clock or 10 O’Clock bulletins but falls in the greyer area of current affairs and discussion, and that Andrew Neil was allowed to deliver provocative monologues on his political shows.John Sweeney, who reported for Newsnight and Panorama before leaving the BBC last year, said that the BBC’s new director-general must “end the chasm” between current affairs and news.One Conservative MP, Daniel Kawczynski, said Maitls’s “aggressive” interviewing style meant Newsnight would struggle to book Tory MPs and ministers in future.Daniel Kawczynski said he had declined to appear on Tuesday’s edition of the show and likened appearing on Newsnight to “entering a bullring”, with interviews akin to a “bloodsport”.On Twitter, he described Maitlis as “extraordinarily aggressive, unnecessarily rude, biased and confrontational to the point of intimidation”.He later told the : “Colleagues will not go on to news channels like Newsnight where it’s more of a theatrical bloodsport than the sensible exchange of views.“This programme, I hope and expect, will wither on the vine because as they fail to get guests more and more people will turn off. If you’re a backbench MP you also have your constituents to think about. Do you want to put yourself on a TV show to be denigrated and humiliated?”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: lockdown causes mounting tensions survey shows britons have
story: Lockdown has seen Britons turn on their neighbours, drink more than usual and gain weight, the first major analysis has shown.King’s College London and Ipsos Mori have been following more than 2,500 people since the second week of lockdown, at the start of April, and have seen significant shifts in behaviour and opinion over time.They found that tensions are mounting in communities, with 17 per cent of people saying they have confronted someone for not following the recommended measures, and nearly one in 10 reporting others to the authorities. Nearly half of those surveyed - 48 per cent - said they had put on weight, while 29 per cent say they are drinking more than they usually would, up from 19 per cent in April.Four in 10 people say they have felt more lonely under lockdown, and 35 per cent have postponed seeking medical advice or treatment that was not linked to coronavirus.One in five workers now think they are fairly likely to lose their jobs, up from 14 per cent in early April. Many people are still so concerned about the virus that they are choosing not to venture outdoors, even though the government’s message has changed from ‘Stay at home’ to ‘Stay alert.’ Four in 10 adults did not leave their home for five or more days in the week leading up to the survey, while one in seven said they did not go out at all. Just 15 per cent of people left their home every day over the same period.Professor Bobby Duffy, Director of the Policy Institute at King’s College London, said: “That four in 10 people did not leave their home for five or more of the previous seven days, with one in seven not leaving their home at all indicates the seriousness with which the public are still treating the Covid-19 crisis.“The UK government’s advice may have shifted to ‘stay alert’, but it’s the ‘stay at home’ message that the public are continuing to follow. “The public’s continued focus on saving lives and protecting health means the government may struggle to coax some people out of lockdown when the rules are eased further.” Yet despite the downsides, many people have started to enjoy aspects of the unprecedented confinement, with one in five saying they have more money than usual left over at the end of the month.The latest results also show people are becoming more resilient to the situation, with many feeling that they can now cope and resigning themselves to long term changes.Nearly half of people - 49 per cent - said that they had enjoyed some aspects of the lockdown measures, while just 26 per cent said there was nothing they had enjoyed.Just over half - 53 per cent - say they are finding coronavirus stressful, down 11 points from 64 per cent last month.Compared with the beginning of April, 38 per cent say the current measures will not become extremely difficult to cope with, up from 26 per cent in the second week of lockdown. Prof Duffy added: “The British public is showing signs of resilience. Not just in keeping to the rules, but also in looking for positives, and engaging in pro-social behaviours like helping others or clapping for carers. “Compared with six weeks ago, compliance to lockdown measures remains high with 92 per cent still following the two-metre rule, 90 per cent hand washing and 89 per cent covering the mouth when coughing. More than half say they are washing or disinfecting items they bring into their homes and 38 per cent are now wearing face masks, double the 19 per cent who had worn them six weeks ago.People are also growing more scared about being hospitalised from the virus, with 40 per cent now thinking they would end up in hospital compared to 30 per cent in April, even though Imperial College estimates the chance to be about 4.4 per cent.Half of people say it would be acceptable for most children to continue to be home-schooled for the very long term if a vaccine or treatment is not found, which researchers described as ‘an extraordinary societal shift.’Gideon Skinner, Research Director at Ipsos MORI, said: “This extensive and detailed study of public opinion and behaviours during the crisis shows that the public are taking the coronavirus very seriously. “As well they might – quite apart from the direct risks, the crisis is having an impact for many people on their financial and mental health too (even though people tend to worry more about others than for themselves). “While many are preparing for the long term, uncertainty continues, and the full impact of the changes the crisis might bring are still to be completely understood.”Yet there are signs that patience with measures is starting to wane. The new figures show that 14 per cent have now had friends or family visit them at home, nearly triple the five per cent who had done the same in the last survey.Nearly one third now say they are certain or very likely to face significant financial difficulties because of the coronavirus, up from 18 per cent six weeks ago.Three in 10 people have had to cut back on non-essential spending, but 21 per cent have had more money left at the end of the month. While 30 per cent have experienced reductions in their income, just six per cent said they had struggled to buy food or essential items and only 5 per cent said they could no longer afford to pay the rent or mortgage. Some 30 per cent of people now do not expect life to return to normal for two or more years, up from nine per cent six weeks ago. The study is based on 2,254 interviews with UK residents aged 16-75, between April 1 to 3 and May 20 - 22.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: people infected coronavirus never show symptoms
story: The vast majority of people who contract coronavirus never show any symptoms, the first analysis of antibody tests by the Office for National Statistics (ONS) has shown, leading to fears the new test, track and trace programme will not work.Under government plans, those showing symptoms are required to self-isolate and be tested while the NHS app will inform people who have been in close contact so they can also quarantine.But new figures show 70 per cent of people testing positive for the virus do not have symptoms at the time of their test, or in the week before or after. Just 21 per cent reported symptoms on the actual day of testing.Likewise for people who reported a symptom on the day of the swab test, only 2.6 per cent were actually found to have coronavirus.  Latest government testing figures also show that just 1.5 per cent of people are currently testing positive for the virus even though most are reporting symptoms.The findings suggest that the government’s test, track and trace policy will fail to pick up at least seven in 10 cases and most people who suffer symptoms will not actually have the virus.Commenting on the new figures, Prof Kevin McConway, Emeritus Professor of Applied Statistics, The Open University, said:  “Most people who tested positive, about 70 per cent of them, did not report any symptoms at all. “There here are potential implications for the effectiveness of tracking and tracing the contacts of people with symptoms, if high numbers of infected people don’t actually have symptoms anyway, or if many people with symptoms don’t actually have the infection.”The results are based on the 885 iniduals who took part in the ongoing Covid-19 Infection Survey run by the ONS and University of Oxford. Peter Benton, Director of Population and Public Policy Operations at the ONS said, that it was crucial to continue social distancing if so many people are infected without realising.“We don’t know what that means about whether they are infectious, but my advice would be that if it is the case that 70 per cent of people who test positive are asymptomatic then it’s important to continue social distancing.”The new results also show that 6.78 per cent of the population has tested positive for the virus, suggesting one in 15 people has been infected in England and Wales or nearly 3.8 million people.It means that infection has around a one per cent average mortality rate, which is close to the 0.9 per cent estimated by Imperial College in March. Separate ONS testing from 10,000 households suggests that between May 11 and May 24 an average of 133,000 people had coronavirus at any given time. The number of new infections is currently at 54,000 a week or nearly 8,000 a day meaning that one in 1,000 people will be infected every seven days. Prof Daniel Altmann, Professor of Immunology, Imperial College London, said: “The level of infections in the community continues to rumble along at a low level. “In terms of assessing your behaviour and risk-management as we shift out of lockdown, this means that, on average, every time you’re in a crowd of 400-500 people (such as a rush-hour tube platform), one person may be unknowingly shedding virus. “You may want to keep some distance in case they’re the person pressed right up next to you.”Experts said the new results showed that there had not been a hidden iceberg of infections, and certainly not enough in the community to build herd immunity without a vaccine. However Sir Patrick Vallance warned that there was still a risk of infection in the community and that the country should be prepared for local outbreaks. “Numbers are coming down at the moment but they are not coming down fast,” he told the daily press briefing.  “We are in a fragile state.“It’s worth remembering that we still have a significant burden of infection, we are still seeing new infections everyday.“There is not a lot of room to do things and things need to be done cautiously step by step and monitored and the test and trace system needs to be effective to manage that.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: double standards show disgrace telegraph readers weeks top
story: Dominic Cummings’ trip to Durham during the height of lockdown has been at the top of the news agenda this week.The Prime Minister's decision to publicly support his special adviser has caused alarm among some members of the Cabinet as well as to many outside of politics. But what happens next? Has Dominic Cummings ultimately survived the calls for him to resign or are there still unanswered questions that must be addressed? Emily Maitlis's Newsnight monologue, the credibility of the UK's lockdown and the prospect of a post-Brexit trade deal with the US have also dominated this week's headlines.  readers have shared their views on all of these, plus much more, below.Read on to see what your fellow readers had to say on the week’s top stories and share your own views in the comments section below. Charles Moore believes that the mean-spirited attempt to destroy Dominic Cummings and unhorse the Prime Minister failed this week.  readers have shared their opinions on what a busy few days in Westminster will mean for Boris Johnson's premiership moving forward. “The Remainer media saw one last chance to reverse or neuter Brexit, by doing down Dominic Cummings and thereby weakening Boris Johnson. That is a perfectly legitimate political aim. But the double standards on show are a disgrace. Labour MPs and Ministers can attend birthday parties, picnics and, regretfully, funerals and no one raises an eyebrow.“Photographers and journalists are cheek by jowl in their desperation to interrogate Mr Cummings, yet not a whisper is heard. The PM’s adviser tries to protect his child and all hell breaks loose. This affair was entirely political nothing to do with public health.”“Dominic Cummings came across very well. Modest, sincere, honest, thoughtful and deeply concerned about his family and country. He managed to shine the light on the media and opposition lies that have contributed to this hysteria and led to public anger, without losing his cool (no mean feat).“The media's questions were repetitive, accusatory and pre-rehearsed and so completely ignored what he had just said – just intended to propagate their own untruths.”“The problem is lack of clarity. Boris Johnson is a master of ambiguity disguising indecision. Very few people have seen or knew where to look for the rather vague rule that gave the right to a parent to take a child somewhere considered to be safer. The constant command was to stay at home. Nothing was said of making one's own judgement to ignore it and no doubt many people could have used Dominic Cummings’ excuse but did not due to unawareness.“Mr Cummings’ total lack of personal charm does not help to appease the public on what appears to be a borderline case of acting properly or not.”In response to the Cummings saga, Newsnight presenter Emily Maitlis caused a political storm on Tuesday evening when she opened the BBC's Newsnight show by announcing: Dominic Cummings broke the rules. The country can see that and it’s shocked the Government cannot. She failed to appear on the show on Wednesday, and the BBC went on to clarify that her monologue from the previous night had breached impartiality guidelines.  readers have had their say on what should happen next. “I have remnants of nostalgia for the once world-renowned BBC. The days of Frost, Day, Walden. The superb drama and documentaries. The informative and thought-provoking news items.  “But, sadly, those days are gone.”“During the 2016 referendum campaign the BBC was scrupulously fair. Once the result came in, however, all bets were off. Dimbleby’s ashen face appeared to be a signal to anyone at the BBC to begin working against the result. Emily Maitlis’s intemperate and incautious monologue was emblematic of that tendency.”Reports have indicated that the Government is looking at new plans to increase outdoor contact by allowing two households to meet up in public next month. Is it a good idea? Here’s what our readers had to say.“Behind the curve again. Round here people have been assessing the rates of Covid-19 and likely risks and close family have had socially distanced meet ups in the garden for some time. It's been known for a very long time that transmission rates in the open air are almost nil. What's the difference between meeting in the garden and all arriving at the supermarket queue at the same time. No logic to any of this.”“Oh for goodness sake, let people see whoever they like in their family. In the first place, how are people expected to choose one of their adult children and possibly set of grandchildren over another? Secondly, isn’t family the easiest track and trace exercise ever? If you’re meeting family you know exactly who was there and in the increasingly unlikely event someone shows symptoms, two or three phone calls is all that’s necessary.”“Most people are doing this already. I feel that the government's policy is actually followership rather than leadership. It is deliberately following public opinion in the hope of not antagonising it. If this is true, it is a demonstrably failed policy. It turns out that in times of threat, the population is actually very grateful for firm and decisive leadership.”Former Environment Secretary Theresa Villiers is calling for food standards to be enshrined into the Agricultural Bill. It is understood that George Eustice, the current Environment Secretary, fears cheap US products will threaten British farmers. But where do  readers stand on the debate?“As markets change so must players in those markets. For 40 years UK farmers have been tied to the EU Museum of Farming aka the CAP designed to benefit French smallholders. Now if farmers want to stay in business they must compete in a different market.“If they cannot lower costs like US farmers they must compete on quality. Many people will buy free range organic chicken over factory farmed chicken and organic beef over American factory farmed beef. That is their choice. The free market is about consumer choice not about defending vested interests.”“I expect the biggest losers in an UK-US FTA will be French farmers who are heavily subsidised by their government. But yes, those British farmers unwilling to follow good business practices may find difficult times ahead.“This may be an excellent time for all British companies to review and improve their business models. After all we are now to become a world trader.”@Death and Taxes“Let customers decide. Personally I don’t care where my chicken comes from as long as I am getting good value for my money.”Allison Pearson, infuriated by the Government’s reluctance to ease further lockdown restrictions, has had enough and booked a holiday in July.  readers, for the most part, appeared to agree that now is the time to slowly resume normal life.“The 14-day quarantine is probably the most insane reaction of this government, even worse than the house arrest of all British citizens. It probably had some value in January and February but why now when the pandemic is fizzling out?”“Surely quarantine should depend on where you’ve returned from. If you’ve been mad enough to holiday in Brazil then, yes, a bit of isolation might be a good idea but if you’ve been to a country with fewer or similar numbers of Covid-19 cases than the UK it’s a fatuous idea.“I had high hopes for Boris Johnson but I’m beginning to wonder.”“I know it's easy to be an armchair critic, and that the Government has had to react to changing situations, but this quarantine idea is bizarre. “It comes on top of the NHS shunting Covid-19 patients into care homes and the abandonment of track and trace in mid-March. I'm afraid I voted for a bunch of muppets.”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: paris gets bike france emerges lockdown cycling 53 per cent
story: The number of cyclists has increased by more than half in Paris since the coronavirus crisis, with many commuters wary of public transport as France emerges from lockdown.Cycling is also gaining popularity in other French cities. The national government and local authorities are encouraging people to avoid crowded metros, buses and trams without resorting to cars.The Paris authorities have created 30 miles of extra cycle routes in the past month, and nearly 50 miles of new bike lanes are to be provided in Lyon this summer.In the two weeks since France began loosening restrictions, bike use has jumped 53 per cent from its pre-lockdown level, according to the Paris city council. “There is undeniably a post-lockdown bike effect,” said Christophe Najdovski, a deputy mayor in charge of transport. “If you create quality cycling lanes, more cyclists appear.”Anne Hidalgo, the mayor, has cut private car use in recent years, pedestrianising the banks of the Seine and restricting traffic in the heavily polluted French capital.Before the Covid-19 pandemic, she promised to create 870 miles of bike lanes by the end of this year. Many Parisians delighted by the cleaner air and decreased noise during lockdown are now backing Ms Hidalgo’s efforts to prevent the city returning to its car-clogged past, despite objections by motorists’ groups.One of Paris’s busiest roads, the rue de Rivoli, which runs past the Louvre museum, has been closed to private cars. It now has four bike lanes and one for buses, taxis and emergency vehicles. France is pumping £17 million into promoting cycling. Bike owners are eligible for free repairs of up to €50 by approved mechanics, and the Paris authority will pay up to €500 (£452) towards the cost of an electric bicycle.“Some economists predict that bike use will overtake cars by 2030, but with the current dynamic that could happen by 2025,” Mr Najdovski said.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: people shielding coronavirus feeling left behind lockdown measures2
story: The heads of almost 50 charities have written to ministers saying the lifting of the lockdown with little reference to those deemed too vulnerable to leave home, is making their burden even harder to bear.Around 2.2 million people classed as extremely vulnerable have spent more than two months shielding, after being issued with advices to stay home completely, and rely on food deliveries and medication being dropped off. When the measures came in, they were told they would last for 12 weeks. Since then, the Government has given no timeframe on when lockdown measures for such people - who including those being treated for cancer, and sufferers from conditions like severe asthma, cystic fibrosis and arthritis - will be lifted. A letter from 48 charity leaders to the Cabinet Office calls for clear guidance on what to do when the current 12-week lockdown period for the most vulnerable ends.And he said some of those confined to their own homes were struggling to access food and medicine, with others making difficult decisions about whether they could return to work.He said: It's simply not acceptable that they just get a message that they are going to have to continue to do this for some time longer, they need to understand what that means and what support is available.Macmillan is hearing from people who feel left behind and forgotten, who got a letter at the start of March telling them to stay in total lockdown, not to leave the house, not to see anyone, to protect themselves.They feel there has been a huge lack of communication to help them understand what lockdown means for them.Other signatories to the letter include the British Lung Foundation, Asthma UK, the MS Society, Versus Arthritis Kidney Care UK and the Cystic Fibrosis Trust. The charities said the impact of the enforced captivity on the mental health of vulnerable people was particularly concerning.Mr Mcintosh said: All of society has been struggling with the impact of lockdown, but for someone with a severe medical condition... already having spent three months in total lockdown without leaving the house, and now spending further months with a lot of uncertainty about what that means for them, that is incredibly bleak and distressing.Many of them feel that they are seeing the days of their lives ticking away without any certainty as to when they are going to be able to see their loved ones, leave their house, or live their lives to the fullest.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker title: travel restrictions uk remains closed europe reopens tourists
story: A number of hotels across the country are already preparing to open their doors to tourism, including the luxury Villa D’Este hotel on Lake ComoWhen can we go on holiday again?Can I take a UK holiday yet? Will holidays be cheaper after coronavirus?Get updates to your inbox three times a week with our Travel newsletterAt the government’s daily press briefing on May 28, Boris Johnson announced imminent changes for schools, retail and social interactions, but the lifting of travel restrictions remained on the backburner. Since his speech on May 10 where it was announced that hotels and restaurants may be able to reopen in England on July 4 at the earliest, there has been no further information. This date is dependent on a number of factors and will not be confirmed until closer to the time. There have been no official statements about a date for when international travel will be allowed again either.Meanwhile, across Europe a number of countries are already beginning to lift restrictions so that domestic and international travel can return in a phased way. Norway has announced it will allow entry to business travellers from all the other Nordic countries, including Sweden, from June 1 with no quarantine required. The inclusion of Sweden was a point of contention, given the country has a significantly higher rate of Covid-19 infections, but in the end Norway opted for a blanket rule.Across the Channel in France, cafés, restaurants and bars can reopen as of June 2. The ban that was in place in regards to distance you are allowed to travel, previously no more than 100km (60 miles), has also been relaxed. France's PM Edouard Philippe said: Freedom will become the rule, bans the exception.Italy will open its borders on June 3, and a number of hotels across the country are already preparing to open their doors to tourism, including the luxury Villa D’Este hotel on Lake Como. Zermatt in Switzerland will reopen for summer skiing on June 6. Slovenia and Hungary also opened their borders to each other on May 28.EuropeanCommissioner for Home Affairs, Ylva Johansson, underlined at the beginning of May: “We need a phased and coordinated approach. Restoring the normal functioning of the Schengen area of free movement is our first objective as soon as the health situation allows it. Restrictions on free movement and internal border controls will need to be lifted gradually before we can remove restrictions at the external borders and guarantee access to the EU for non-EU residents for non-essential travel.”The Canadian Government has extended its ban on cruise ships until the end of October 2020, the country's transport minister has announced. The ban will apply to cruise ships with more than 100 people, including both passengers and crew. Canada had originally closed its borders to all cruise ships with more than 500 onboard until July 1.Cruise ban leaves &#39America&#39s last frontier&#39 even less accessibleThe news means that operating cruises to Alaska or New England will be effectively impossible because US cabotage laws require foreign-flagged vessels departing a US port to first call on a distant foreign port before returning to the United States and most vessels operate under a flag of convenience.Read our story on what a missed cruise season means for Alaska.A pilot is being investigated for breaking lockdown rules and trespassing by landing his plane on a closed RAF airfield in North Wales because he wanted to go to the beach.The pilot of the Pilatus PC12 landed on a runway at RAF Valley on the island of Anglesey, sparking an emergency response from Ministry of Defence (MoD) guards and fire crews.It is understood that, upon landing, he taxied his single-engine turboprop plane to the far side of the airfield, near the beach, where he was confronted by guards.The pilot was believed to have flown from an airfield in Surrey as he wanted to go to the beach, despite it being in breach of the coronavirus lockdown rules for Wales, a source told the PA news agency.Can we go to the beach during UK lockdown? Latest advice here.The last few months have seen the biggest change in travelling habits in peacetime. Never before has such a huge proportion of the human race simply withdrawn into its shell and stayed at home. We still have no clear idea how long we will be grounded, but we can be sure that, when we finally emerge and start to travel again, the world will be a different place.One of the questions regarding the longer-term consequences of Covid-19 that consumers will likely already be considering concerns the cost of their holiday. Will we end having to pay more or less for travel? Will holidays abroad become the prerogative of the rich?Nick Trend has the answers here.The Italian Lakes are preparing to welcome tourists for the summer season, with Lake Como's Mandarin Oriental and Villa d'Este announcing a reopening date of June 18. This will come exactly a month after the popular Borromean Islands of Lake Maggiore, and the botanical gardens there, reopened to visitors.Mandarin Oriental on Lake Como will reopen on June 18Villa d'Este, described by  Travel's Kiki Deere as one of the world's most celebrated hotels, will reopen in phases, beginning with its historic main Cardinal building and private villas, alongside the Sundeck Bar, Terrazza Bar and Sporting Club. The Veranda Restaurant will also be open to guests and locals. The Queen’s Pavilion is set to open at a later date, depending on demand, similarly The Grill and Il Platano will follow later in the season. Mandarin Oriental will also have a range of new health and safety measures in place.You can view a full calendar of when European hotels plan to reopen here.Britons could have to take 20-minute coronavirus tests before arriving at the airport under proposals being considered by ministers as part of a bid to enable holidays abroad this summer, reveal Harry Yorke and Charles Hymas.An expert committee of scientists, ministers, civil servants and aviation chiefs is considering tests that would enable travellers to sidestep quarantine and could be used to replace travel restrictions.The 14-day quarantine for all international arrivals to the UK - including returning Britons - is due to be introduced on June 8 requiring them to self-isolate for 14 days.Read the full exclusive story here.It’s a curious paradox: escaping the city during a European city break. Yet once we can travel again (perhaps thanks to bilateral travel agreements, or air bridges, which would circumvent quarantine measures) the pandemic is set to alter the experience for the foreseeable future. Socially distanced, or strictly al fresco, dining, reduced capacity at major attractions and obligatory face masks may greet us in tourist hot spots – but their pretty tracts of greenery will provide a slice of normality. Travel’s destination experts share their favourite city parks in this story, from Berlin to Barcelona – for when we can travel again. A report by Reuters today shared that The National Statistics Institute (INE) in Portugal said in its flash estimate that the number of overnight stays by foreign tourists in Portugal dropped 98.3 per cent to nearly 71,000 last month from the previous year. Naturally, grounded flights and international travel bans are the main reason for this sudden drop.Lockdown is being gradually eased in Portugal now though – restaurants, cafes, museums and art galleries were included in the second stage of reopening on May 18, the third stage is set to begin in June.Foreign Minister Augusto Santos Silva said on May 22 that the country was open to international visitors. “Tourists are welcome in Portugal,” Mr Silva told the Observador newspaper, adding that some health checks would be carried out at airports but that there would be no compulsory quarantine for arrivals.For the latest information on when British holidaymakers will be able to visit Portugal, click here.France is to reopen bars, cafés and restaurants and lift internal travel restrictions from June 2 as part of “phase 2” of its lockdown exit plan. These venues will be allowed inside and out in green-zone mainland France (all but its north-east regions, which are red), except in Paris (orange), which will be outdoor-only. Cultural venues including museums, theatres and monuments can also reopen from this date, and travel between green zones will also be allowed.Border restrictions with European countries without quarantine measures will be removed from June 15. This means there will be no quarantine exemptions between the UK and France.France has unveiled the second phase of its exit plan, easing travel restrictions and reopening bars and restaurants next weekThe hospitality industry must prepare for tables to be at least 1m apart, seating a maximum of 10 people each, staff to wear masks, and the same for guests when moving around inside the restaurant (e.g. to the loo). Physical menus are not allowed only oral, chalk board or digital.Find out more about when we will be able to visit France again here. TfL’s former headquarters are to be turned into a luxury 526-room hotel after being given the green light on plans, reports Charlotte Johnstone.Located above London's St James' Park station, the Grade-I listed 55 Broadway Complex was built in 1929 in an early-modernist style as the headquarters of the Underground Electric Railways of London Ltd before it became London Transport in 1933. The landmark is widely described as “London’s first skyscraper” and was designed by the renowned architect Charles Holden, the visionary behind many other London Underground stations, Imperial War Graves Commission and Bristol Central Library. The large tower at the top and roof terraces will be turned into a restaurant and rooftop bar promising excellent views across London. There is no word on when it’s set to open yet, but when it does we are assured that restoration has been sympathetic and reimagined with the building’s heritage in mind.   From June 15, the Lufthansa Group Airlines will resume services from major UK and Ireland ports with 115 weekly frequencies in total. This will incorporate an increase in frequencies from both London Heathrow and Dublin, as well as eight new routes from five hubs across the UK and Ireland. Lufthansa hopes to reinstate services to 130 destinations by the end of June.This marks a significant expansion in the second half of June compared to previous weeks.Andreas Köster, Senior Director Sales UK, Ireland and Iceland for the Lufthansa Group carriers says,By resuming a part of our schedule in June, the Lufthansa Group is building up mobility by connecting the UK and Ireland again to our world-wide network. This is an important contribution to support the restart of industry and commerce, but also the tourism sector - both essential for the UK and Irish economy. People want to and can travel again, whether on holiday or for business reasons.Hugh Morris of  Travel has the latest advice on when flights will resume.A new normal is starting to emerge on the Canary Islands, where beaches are already open. Concerts and events will soon be able to be enjoyed live too, rather than virtually, as they have been over the previous weeks. This is now possible following measures established by the Spanish Public Health.In fact, Las Palmas de Gran Canaria's Teatro Guiniguada, will open its doors to the public today, May 29, with a performance from Islazz, by Yul Ballesteros. The concert, with limited seating, is set to begin at 8.30pm. It will be Spain's first concert in front of a live audience since lockdown began, and marks the beginning of the reactivation of the country's cultural scene.This is further to the news last week that the Canary Islands hopes to welcome a group of British tourists as early as July, to test out new technology and social distancing protocols being introduced on the islands.Environmentally friendly, self-sufficient eco-pods, that can be towed on a trailer or shipped anywhere in the world, could transform the way we go on holiday in the post Covid-19 era.The egg-shaped Ecocapsules, designed by Slovakian design firm Nice Architects, can house two people for a year off the grid, with the luxuries of a warm bed, running water and hot food.These off-the-grid pods could change camping foreverToday, Ecocapsule has launched a lower-price Ecocapsule for the post Covid-19 traveller. The capsule will set you back a lean €49,900 (£45,000).Here's the full story.Never has a summer season been so critical for ski resorts in the French Alps, where winter seasons were cut abruptly short by lockdown in mid-March.The historic resort of Chamonix, which usually attracts around 4 million visitors in summer, is expecting 40 per cent of last year’s visitors in summer 2020. However, Claire Burnet of Chamonix Mont-Blanc Tourism remains optimistic :We do believe there will be an increase in holidaymakers travelling to the mountains rather than beach resorts, which tend to be more crowded. The Chamonix Valley extends over 28km many accommodation options and 400km of marked hiking trails make it very easy to get off the beaten track and stay in one's own bubble.Read the full report here.Scott Williams, the luxury villa specialist known for its beautiful rental houses in France, Spain, Italy, Greece, Croatia and Morocco, has launched a new collection of houses and hotels to rent in the UK, reports Jade Conroy.The portfolio currently includes 11 properties in some of the UK’s most-desirable holiday destinations. Most interesting is the fact that the portfolio includes two hotels, both available to book out in their entirety: Heckfield Place, a stylish country house hotel in Hampshire with exceptional artworks, and Number One Bruton, a new 12-bedroom hotel by Michelin-starred chef Merlin Labron-Johnson (the latter costs £9,600 per week, up to 16 sharing). The hotel Heckfield Place is part of Scott Williams&#39s new UK villa portfolioVictoria Hooberman, founder of Scott Williams comments,Already known for our ability to arrange additional services, including chefs, yoga instructors and spa therapists, all our new UK properties will offer optional extras – including the services of your very own Michelin starred chef at some.With travel restrictions for the UK summer uncertain, booking terms are flexible – deposits are paid but if travel or group gatherings of the party’s size are not permitted at the time of travel, then full refunds will be issued. Stays will only go ahead in accordance with government guidelines.  Can you book a holiday in the UK yet? Read the latest travel advice from Nick Trend.Spirit of Adventure will not be delivered in time for its inaugural voyage, reports Benjamin Parker. The new ship – sister to Spirit of Discovery, which launched in 2019 – had been due to sail on August 21, 2020. A spokesperson for the Saga cruise line said:Progress has been severely impacted by the workplace and travel restrictions in place as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic. We have written to our customers to let them know and offered them the chance of amending over to the new date once confirmed or to receive a full refund.Click here for an up-to-date list of when cruise lines are planning to sail again. When Gavin Bell's flight home to the UK from Cape Town was cancelled a month ago after the country’s borders closed to commercial air traffic, he and his family found themselves stranded with no way out.Since then, despite the country’s strict lockdown, Covid-19 infections and deaths have been rising with hospital admissions doubling every five days and threatening to overwhelm health services. Hungry crowds had clashed with riot police, food stores were being looted, and at the last count 1,775 schools had been burgled, vandalised and burned.The situation is expected to become far worse before it gets better.So when the British High Commission announced ten repatriation flights from Cape Town and Johannesburg – he was among the first to put his name on the list.Read the full story here.Online booking platform Hotels has spotted an increase of 160 per cent in searches for accommodation near Barnard Castle from May 22-27 compared with the previous week. The influx of interest is likely attributed to the news that Dominic Cummings visited the Teesdale market town on April 12, which he confirmed in his press conference on May 25. Reports that Cummings had been seen at Barnard Castle in April first began to circulate on May 23.Is the small market town worth a visit? Benjamin Parker has the answer.Zermatt has announced it will be opening its glacier, which lies in the shadow of the iconic Matterhorn mountain, for summer skiing and snowboarding, plus mountain biking and walking, from June 6.The decision follows new permissions granted by the Swiss government to allow mountain lift systems across the country to lift the shutters – which were prematurely closed in March as coronavirus spread across Europe.In order to reopen Zermatt has introduced a number of rules. While there won’t be a limit on capacity in lifts people must remain two metres away from each other when in gondola cabins and station buildings. If they cannot maintain this distance they are advised to wear a face covering, which are available to buy from lift stations. Skiers are also encouraged to purchase lift tickets online in advance or use contactless payment methods when they arrive. Groups no larger than four will be able to eat together at the glacier’s restaurant, where tables will be two metres apart.The news comes as other resorts in Europe, which have access to high-altitude snow-sure glaciers, prepare to open for the summer season. Leading the charge, the Austrian resort of Hintertux in the Zillertal valley opened its glacier today, as did the Kitzsteinhorn glacier above Zell am See.Find out which other ski resorts are planning a summer of snow sports here.Nights On Us, a brand new initiative from the travel industry that hopes to offer two-night hotel breaks for all ICU frontline workers, launched this morning. More than 3,500 nights have been confirmed so far from leading UK hotels including Belmond Le Manoir aux Quat'Saisons, The Savoy, The Doyle Collection, Brown's Hotel, Grantley Hall and Farncombe Estate.Nights On Us is underpinned by collaboration and we believe that by bringing the hotel sector together, we will be able to thank for more of these incredible people as an unided unit. Our target is to provide 100,000 hotel stays for NHS ICU workers. A pair of alluring bathtubs at The Fish in the Cotswolds, which has donated 30 nights to the initiativeOnce the relevant lockdown measures are lifted and UK hotels are able to open again, the Nights On Us booking portal will open to all ICU workers who will be able to secure their much deserved break. Read the full story here.Yesterday, Tui announced the cancellation of all its holidays until June 30 2020 the tour operator had initially only axed trips until June 11. River Cruises are the category that will see the most serious change in the number of departures this year though, with all sailings up until and including November 25 now no longer going ahead. The brand’s Lakes and Mountain holidays are also axed up until September 30.Hundreds of thousands of British holidaymakers will be affected, though customers whose trips have been cancelled are entitled to a full refund. The process for this begins with a refund form on the Tui website. That said, Tui is encouraging its package holiday customers to rebook by offering a 20 per cent bonus refund credit for those that do. For example, if you paid £2,000 for your holiday booking, you will now have £2,400 to spend. The operator says: All other holidays are continuing to operate as planned and will be continuously reviewed. Want to know when to reschedule your holiday? title: couriers coronavirus testing samples delivery strike doctors laboratory
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Riders allege&nbspNHS contractor The Doctors&nbspLaboratory proposed to make certain employees redundant because they campaigned for better working conditionsMedical couriers delivering coronavirus testing samples for the NHS have voted to strike after the company employing them refused to offer the riders themselves tests.They also allege that NHS contractor The Doctors Laboratory (TDL) targeted eight couriers for redundancy because they had been active in campaigning for improved working conditions.The move is potentially another blow for the government’s new system to test and trace coronavirus infections which has been criticised by clinicians who say it is not ready, despite ministers’ assurances.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesOn Thursday, couriers employed by TDL, a subsidiary of Australian firm Sonic Healthcare, announced they had decided to take industrial action after the company failed to address their health and safety concerns.A letter sent by TDL’s chief executive to one courier on 20 March stated that drivers would not be tested by the company as the government’s advice at the time was that this would add “no value”. Regular testing of couriers is still not being carried out but those with symptoms are now being tested, TDL said on Thursday.Whether ‘test and trace’ has been rushed or not – it’s a poor launchTDL describes itself as the “largest UK independent provider of highly specialised pathologyclinical laboratory services to clinicians (GPs and specialists), hospitals, community health services, and their patients”.Its network of couriers collect and drop off medical samples such as blood tests from hospitals and surgeries before delivering them to labs for analysis. During the pandemic they have entered hospitals with a high number of Covid-19 patients to pick up testing samples.The Independent Workers’ Union of Great Britain (IWGB), which represents the couriers, says that this potentially puts them at high risk of infection but the company has not engaged with their safety requests. The union wants regular testing and adequate personal protective equipment (PPE), as well as full sick pay for workers who need to self-isolate because they are aged over 60 or have pre-existing medical conditions. It also alleges that TDL has not implemented proper social distancing in the company’s loading bay.The IWGB has filed a trade union and whistleblower victimisation claim against the company at the employment tribunal on behalf of eight of its members, who say they were targeted for redundancy on “bogus” grounds.The eight workers believe the company is attempting to make them redundant because of their involvement in previous disputes over issues including rider safety and pay.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailTDL strongly rejected the IWGB’s allegations. It said only 46 of its 157-strong workforce had voted to strike based on “unfounded” allegations which the company categorically denies. IWGB said that 84 per cent of members who returned their ballots voted in favour of industrial action.A TDL spokesperson added: “It is inconceivable that TDL would deliberately expose any of its workforce, of whom its courier fleet is an important part, to undue risk at any time but especially now. “All TDL’s health and safety protocols, which includes access to Covid-19 testing for those with symptoms, are compliant with current regulations and UK Government guidelines, are kept under constant review by TDL’s director of health and safety, and when they change, TDL’s protocols change with them.”The company said it proposed to make its team of 10 bicycle couriers redundant because of a downturn in the London area where they operate. A final decision has not yet been made.TDL cycle courier and IWGB couriers and logistics branch chair Alex Marshall said: “I’m incredibly proud of the work we have done during this pandemic. “TDL’s cycle couriers are among the best in the industry, have an impeccable attendance record and in times of tremendous stress have provided a model service to the community. “Instead of rewarding us, management has decided to take away our only means to feed our families in the middle of a pandemic. But the resounding vote in favour of strike action shows that despite management’s attempts to break us, we are more united than ever.”Labour MP and former shadow chancellor John McDonnell tweeted in support of the couriers who he said had been “pushed to the limit” by their employer.Coronavirus: One in 15 people tested show signs of infectionTest and trace system plunged into chaos as NHS staff unable to log inTest and trace ‘won’t be fully operational until end of next month’What it’s like to work as a hospital chaplain on the Covid frontline“This issue needs to be addressed urgently by @MattHancock if the plan for testing &amp tracking is to be effective,” Mr McDonnell wrote. “Sacking these couriers playing a key role in helping tackle the pandemic is completely counterproductive.”The government’s test, track and trace system got off to a stuttering start on Thursday, when an army of 25,000 contact tracers had been due to begin work.The programme’s first day was beset by problems and the government has admitted it will not be “fully operational” until the end of June.Several contact tracers told The Independent that they could not access the website when it launched on Thursday morning, with staff left unable to work.It is hoped track and trace will allow the country to come out of lockdown while still keeping control of coronavirus case numbers but title: earth exoplanet space universe proxima centauri espresso
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The planet, called Proxima b, is approximately 4.2 light years away. If it has water and oxygen, it could potentially be home to&nbspalien lifeA planet the size of Earth has been confirmed around the closest star in our solar system, Proxima Centauri, by an international team of scientists.The planet, called ‘Proxima b’, has a mass of 1.17 Earths and is located in the habitable zone of Proxima Centauri, which the planet orbits approximately every 11 days, according to the new paper published in the journal Astronomy &amp Astrophysics.The first indications of the planet’s existence were in 2013 by Mikko Tuomi of the University of Hertfordshire from archival observation data, with continued research following in 2016. It is believed this planet could be “likely” to be able to support alien life forms.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe researchers detected this planet by measuring radial velocity using the Echelle SPectrograph for Rocky Exoplanets and Stable Spectroscopic Observations (ESPRESSO) which is installed on a telescope in Chile. It is three times as accurate as HARPS, another spectrograph which has been used to measure the velocity of Proxima Centauri.Radial velocity, in relation to a given point, is the rate of change of the distance between an object and that point. As a planet orbits a star, its gravitational pull causes a star to move back and forth. This tiny motion shifts the observed light spectrum of the star slightly due to Doppler shift, which can be detected with sensitive instruments.Everything you need to know about SpaceX launchA low disturbance in Proxima Centauri’s speed, detected by ESPRESSO, tipped researchers off to the presence of the planet. Nobel Prize-winning astrophysicist Michel Mayor said that ESPRESSO makes it possible to “measure the mass of the planet with a precision of over one-tenth of the mass of Earth”, which he describes as “completely unheard of.Proxima Centauri is approximately 4.2 light-years from the Sun, but Nasa estimates it would take approximately 73,000 years for us to reach the planet unless new technologies are developed.Ionic propulsion, nuclear thermal propulsion, nuclear pulse propulsion, fusion rockets, and laser sails have all been considered as methods to travel to the planet.Mysterious signals coming from space answer matter puzzle30 years of space wonder began with a vital but underwhelming imageSpace Force launch: Robotic rocket plane blasts off on secret missionAstronomers find 'regular rhythms' coming from distant starsSpace debris from failed rocket misses New York City by minutes“We were already very happy with the performance of HARPS, which has been responsible for discovering hundreds of exoplanets over the last 17 years,” said Francesco Pepe, a professor in the Astronomy Department in UNIGE’s Faculty of Science in a statement. “We’re really pleased that ESPRESSO can produce even better measurements, and it’s gratifying and just reward for the teamwork lasting nearly 10 years.”Alejandro Suarez Mascareño, the article’s main author, said: “Confirming the existence of Proxima b was an important task, and it’s one of the most interesting planets known in the solar neighbourhood.”Although Proxima b is about 20 times closer to its star than the Earth is to the Sun, it receives comparable amounts of energy. If there is liquid form on the planet, it could harbour life, but researchers said there is still much to be done before that can be confirmed. “Is there an atmosphere that protects the planet from these deadly rays?” said Christophe Lovis, a researcher in the University of Geneva’s Astronomy Department, “and if this atmosphere exists, does it contain the chemical elements that promote the development of life?”It is also possible that there could be a second planet orbiting the star, as the research team found evidence of a second signal in the data – but was unable to determine its origins. “If the signal was planetary in origin, this potential other planet accompanying Proxima b would have a mass less than one third of the mass of the Earth. It would then be the smallest planet ever measured using the radial velocity method,” said Professor Pepe.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus uk tests how many daily number figure chart
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.New target of capacity of 200,000 tests a day set by governmentAfter the government declared it had met its goal of providing 100,000 coronavirus tests a day by the end of April – a claim contested amid accusations of data manipulation – a new target for May has been set.As authorities prepare to ease certain lockdown measures, Downing Street announced that it is aiming to increase capacity to 200,000 tests a day by the end of the month.But the Department for Health and Social Care has repeatedly failed to provide a daily testing figure in May, an omission which No 10 has been unable to explain.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe government has acknowledged that large-scale testing and contact tracing will be vital to ending the lockdown, having promised in the earlier stages of the pandemic to eventually deliver 250,000 tests a day.This pledge has since been watered down, with Downing Street stressing that the latest target set by the PM relates only to testing capacity and not to the number of tests actually carried out.Since health secretary Matt Hancock announced that more than 122,000 tests had been carried out on the final day of April, the daily testing figure has frequently dropped below the 100,000 and is typically tens of thousands fewer than the “capacity” available.Under the latest government guidelines, anyone over 65 years old with symptoms of Covid-19 will be able to get tested for the virus.Care home residents and staff will also be able to access tests, even if they do not have symptoms, as well as asymptomatic NHS patients and staff.People who leave their homes to work, and are displaying signs of coronavirus, are similarly eligible for testing.The UK has performed far fewer tests relative to its population than other badly affected countries, like Italy and Spain.Less than 2 per cent of the UK's population has so far been tested for coronavirus.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email The four-part documentary features the testimonies of multiple survivors who say they were abused by the disgraced financier.Its first episode focuses in part on an investigation conducted in 2011 by journalist Vicky Ward for Vanity Fair.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAccording to Ward, Epstein became threatening when he found out Ward was working on a piece about him, telling her that if he didn’t “like” it, “it’s going to be bad for you and your family”.19 best limited series for TV commitment-phobesThe best Amazon Prime and Netflix shows to watch while self-isolatingNetflix to automatically cancel ‘hundreds of thousands’ of accountsJeffrey Epstein: Netflix documentary brings to light new allegationsThe journalist goes on to recall a phone call from Carter, in which she says he shared additional concerning news.“He was pretty spooked because he’d found a severed cat head in his garden,” Ward says.“He also found a bullet on his doorstep.”Ward goes on to state that part of her story with testimony from two women who shared allegations against Epstein were ultimately taken out, which she attributed to an editorial decision on the magazine’s part.Carter disputed Ward’s recollection in a statement provided to the documentary and said that parts of Ward’s reporting “did not meet our legal threshold” at the time. The issue has now been resolved and we apologise for any inconvenience this may have caused.The outage came as users across the country rely on their connections to work and study from home. While the internet infrastructure has stayed largely stable despite the new working patterns, any outage can very quickly cause widespread problems.Problems were reported right across the country, according to Down Detector. title: twitter schedule tweets how to tweet
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The functionality has been rolled out to Twitter's web client, but will not save content between its website and smartphone appsTwitter has announced a new feature for its platform: the ability to schedule tweets. The function also allows users to save drafts of their tweets in the web app, similar to what users can already do on its iOS and Android applications.However, these drafts are not saved across platforms tweets that you save via its website will only be available on the website, and won’t be available on your phone or other device.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesTo schedule a tweet, go to Twitter’s site on your laptop or desktop computer, type your tweet, and click the newly-appeared schedule button. You can then set the date and time for when you want the tweet to be published.Another new button – ‘Scheduled Tweets’ – will let you see all the tweets you’re yet to publish and, should you have changed your mind about sharing one, is where you delete them.Twitter is also experimenting with other changes to the platform: it is currently testing a setting where a small number of users can control who replies to their tweets. Users can decide whether they want everyone to be able to reply, only the people they follow, only people they directly mention in the tweet, or nobody at all.The company is also testing asking users to “revise” their language when tweeting rude or harmful content, and a way to see who has replied to your tweet in a quoted-tweet.Trump claiming to use 'powers he does not have' to shut down TwitterZuckerberg says Twitter shouldn't be 'arbiter of truth'This is the most honest Trump has ever been with the American peopleTwitter refuses widower's plea to remove trolling Trump tweetsThis news comes as the social media site is being challenged by Donald Trump over decisions to took to fact-check one of his tweets that made misleading claims about the relationship between postal voting and election fraud. Mr Trump has since signed an executive order against the company limiting its protection under Section 230, a law which which prevents tech firms from being held legally responsible for the content they allow on their sites. Following riots in Minneapolis after a man called George Floyd died in police custody, Mr Trump tweeted a message calling the protestors “thugs” and said “when the looting starts, the shooting starts. Thank you!”Twitter added a label hiding the tweet, saying that it “violated the Twitter Rules about glorifying violence”. However, Twitter will not take the tweet down as the company says it “has determined that it may be in the public’s interest for the tweet to remain accessible”Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Women doing&nbspmore household chores than fathers by average of 12 hoursMothers in the UK are having to do an additional 31 hours more housework each week than they did before the coronavirus crisis, a study has found.The report, carried out by Boston Consulting Group, warned this extra work is equivalent to having a second job and is causing a tremendous amount of stress.Researchers found women are doing an average of 12 hours more household chores than fathers are.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesParents’ lives have been massively disrupted by the Covid-19 lockdown due to nurseries, primary schools, secondary schools and sixth forms being forced to close across the UK in an attempt to stop the spread of the virus.The research into working parents found the additional emergency due to additional domestic duties, while 49 per cent of fathers said the same. Researchers found 70 per cent of parents do not have any type of external support in providing care and education for their children.The study, which polled 3,055 working parents in the UK, America, France, Germany, and Italy, found similar gendered patterns in other countries too.Researchers found women with children across these countries now spend an average of 65 hours a week on unpaid labour around the house — with this figure having almost doubled since the Covid-19 crisis. This is almost a third more than fathers, who are doing an average of 50 hours a week.It comes after a study by the London School of Economics recently found coronavirus is exacerbating the gender gap as women bear the brunt of childcare responsibilities and homeschooling during lockdown — whether they’re working or not.I founded the Wages for Housework campaign – little has changed sinceThe report found women are more likely to deal with homeschooling, childcare and chores around the house even if they are juggling this with working at the same time.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus lockdown uk date travel
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Data suggests travel, socialising and other&nbsppre-lockdown&nbsphabits could be impacted long after containment measures endMobility data from Apple has revealed that the coronavirus outbreak was already having a significant impact on people's behaviour long before the government imposed lockdown restrictions.In the weeks before the UK entered lockdown on 23 March, companies began to introduce measures like working from home in order to help contain the spread of the virus. This trend, combined with people's own changing attitudes toward social events and large gatherings, resulted in travel dropping by more than 50 per cent before the lockdown began, according to requests made on Apple Maps for car and public transport directions.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesRequests on Apple Maps for car directions began to fall on 11 March, while requests for public transport directions began to fall even earlier on 9 March.Many activities and behaviours that were considered normal before coronavirus also remain taboo regardless of the government's guidelines.The recently relaxed rules mean that cleaners and nannies are now permitted to visit people's homes, but a recent survey found that the majority of people found this very unacceptable.The poll by Ipsos MORI, which was carried out between 8 and 11 May, also found that having non co-habiting friends, family members or loved ones visit was also considered socially unacceptable.​Public opinion about exercise and driving is more greatly ided, ​though the poll demonstrated that government rules may not be a defining influence on people's behaviours.Companies' decisions to keep work from home policies in place show that lockdown measures are not necessarily enforced by government policy decision.The figures also suggest that the impact of coronavirus on travel habits, socialising and other pre-lockdown habits could continue long after lockdown officially ends.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: help the hungry damien hirst donate feeding vulnerable people
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.New landmark has enabled delivery of more than three million meals since&nbsplockdown beganOur Help the Hungry appeal soared past £5.5 million today after a £1.5m boost from sales of the Damien Hirst butterfly heart print created especially for our campaign.In the two months since our appeal began, we have helped our campaign partner The Felix Project deliver more than three million meals to hundreds of thousands of vulnerable people, alongside our sister title, the Evening Standard. The Felix Project has supplied 1,376 tons of produce since 23 March, the equivalent of 3,276,190 meals. This support has ameliorated the deep distress of those unable to afford or access food – in particular, families struggling below the breadline, NHS workers and the elderly.The sum raised from sales of Hirst’s rainbow butterfly hearts means that we are more than halfway to our goal of securing £10m for The Felix Project to help food-poor Londoners over the next three years. It is a pledge given added urgency by the latest jobless claims, which have surged to more than two million.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMore than 4,400 people backed our campaign by purchasing the Hirst limited edition prints – 3,109 bought the small size, costing £300 each, and 1,299 bought the large size, costing £1,000.Mr Hirst said: “It’s amazing to see how people have pulled together and helped each other during this crisis. I am so grateful to everyone who has helped me do my little bit and bought a butterfly heart edition – it’s turned out to be a brilliant communal way to help raise money for The Felix Project and support their important work across London.”How to support our campaignEvgeny Lebedev, shareholder in The Independent, said: “I have long believed in the power of art and this is a wonderful affirmation of that. With the support of Damien Hirst we have passed the halfway point in our mission to ensure no Londoner in any corner of the city goes hungry because of Covid.”Other substantial new donors to our campaign include management consultants McKinsey &amp Company, whose employees voted to make our appeal partner their charity of choice.Olga Nefedova, associate partner, said: “We are making a donation to organisations helping our most vulnerable communities. The Felix Project is very much one of these organisations.”So far, more than six million meals have been delivered by the London Food Alliance – established in response to the coronavirus pandemic and made up of Felix, FareShare and City Harvest – of which over half have been supplied by The Felix Project.Mark Curtin, CEO of The Felix Project, paid tribute to the extraordinary all-round effort. “London was hit hard and fast – but oh, how it has stepped up and fought back,” he said. “We are inspired by the mobilisation of businesses, donors and supporters who have joined forces with our staff and volunteers.” The Independent is encouraging readers to help groups that are trying to feed the hungry during the crisis. Premium.Lizzie Edmonds&nbspmeets volunteers from an Acton estate helping with food parcels during the coronavirus lockdownTucked beneath a development of luxury flats in west London is a hive of community activity with some unexpected stars helping to feed families who have found themselves with nothing during the coronavirus crisis.Twice a week, a team of young volunteers – most of whom live on the challenging South Acton council estate – have been volunteering to sort goods from The Felix Project, our Help The Hungry campaign partner, into boxes, which are then handed out to some of London’s poorest families.The team, lead by Colin Brent (a youth worker at Ealing Council), work from a small space adjacent to the Bollo Brook Youth Centre.Sharing the full story, not just the
